_source.content:
Triple Vaccinated General Milley Tests Positive For Covid

The United States chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff has tested positive for COVID-19.

Joint Chiefs Chairman Mark Milley reported testing positive for COVID-19 on Sunday and is working remotely, according to a spokesperson.

Milley is ‚Äúexperiencing very minor symptoms and can perform all of his duties from the remote location. He has received the COVID-19 vaccines, including the booster,‚Äù the spokesperson said in a statement.

Milley‚Äôs last contact with President Joe Biden was on Wednesday, Jan. 12, at Gen. Raymond T. Odierno‚Äôs funeral, the spokesperson said. Milley ‚Äútested negative several days prior to and every day following contact with the President until yesterday,‚Äù the spokesperson said.

Milley was not the only member of the Joint Chiefs of Staff to test positive for COVID-19.

‚ÄúThe Commandant of the Marine Corps, Gen. David Berger, has tested positive for COVID-19. The performance of his duties will remain unaffected,‚Äù Maj. Eric Flanagan, the spokesman for the commandant of the Marine Corps, said in a statement.

Milley and Berger are the latest Pentagon officials to test positive for COVID-19. Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin tested positive for COVID-19 on Jan. 2.

While the military has been actively encouraging its members to get vaccines, service members have reported that getting religious exemptions for the vaccine mandate has been challenging. Only two Marines have reported getting exemptions.

card.description: A Bronx home exploded in flames and collapsed Tuesday, leaving an 82-year-old woman clinging to life and at least nine other people hurt, including five cops, officials said.
card.title: Fiery Bronx explosion leaves woman critical, 9 others injured ‚Äî including 5 cops

_source.content: https://nypost.com/2022/01/18/fiery-nyc-house-explosion-injures-residents-5-cops/A Bronx home exploded in flames Tuesday during a possible gas leak, killing a 77-year-old woman and injuring at least eight others, officials said.Two sisters, including the woman who perished, were inside the building when it exploded, and both were found laying on the ground outside when emergency responders arrived on scene, the FDNY said. The surviving sister is in critical condition, and a third woman, who was in a neighboring unit that was badly damaged by the explosion, has serious injuries, the FDNY said. The third woman became trapped in her home, and NYPD officers rushed in and carried her out, Mayor Eric Adams said.The badly injured women are ages 82 and 68, according to the NYPD. Five cops also suffered injuries from smoke inhalation and are in stable condition, authorities said. A fire scene in the Bronx on Southern Blvd and Intervale Avenue. The home on Fox Street near Intervale Avenue in Longwood shown before and after the explosion.‚ÄúThis is a serious tragedy,‚Äù said Lt. Gov. Brian Benjamin at the scene. ‚ÄúMy heart goes out to the families who‚Äôve been affected. The governor and I will make sure that the state does everything it can, financially and otherwise, to help these homeowners who have been impacted by this tragedy.‚Äù Approximately 200 firefighters and EMS officials responded to the home on Fox Street near Intervale Avenue in Longwood just before 11 a.m., about 4 minutes after they received reports of an explosion and collapse, the FDNY said.Photos showed flames engulfing the building, and later, thick plumes of smoke still rising from the leveled home‚Äôs debris as dozens of firefighters worked the scene.
_source.contentraw:
https://nypost.com/2022/01/18/fiery-nyc-house-explosion-injures-residents-5-cops/
A Bronx home exploded in flames Tuesday during a possible gas leak, killing a 77-year-old woman and injuring at least eight others, officials said.

Two sisters, including the woman who perished, were inside the building when it exploded, and both were found laying on the ground outside when emergency responders arrived on scene, the FDNY said.

The surviving sister is in critical condition, and a third woman, who was in a neighboring unit that was badly damaged by the explosion, has serious injuries, the FDNY said. The third woman became trapped in her home, and NYPD officers rushed in and carried her out, Mayor Eric Adams said.

The badly injured women are ages 82 and 68, according to the NYPD.

Five cops also suffered injuries from smoke inhalation and are in stable condition, authorities said.

A fire scene in the Bronx on Southern Blvd and Intervale Avenue.

The home on Fox Street near Intervale Avenue in Longwood shown before and after the explosion.
‚ÄúThis is a serious tragedy,‚Äù said Lt. Gov. Brian Benjamin at the scene.

‚ÄúMy heart goes out to the families who‚Äôve been affected. The governor and I will make sure that the state does everything it can, financially and otherwise, to help these homeowners who have been impacted by this tragedy.‚Äù

Approximately 200 firefighters and EMS officials responded to the home on Fox Street near Intervale Avenue in Longwood just before 11 a.m., about 4 minutes after they received reports of an explosion and collapse, the FDNY said.

Photos showed flames engulfing the building, and later, thick plumes of smoke still rising from the leveled home‚Äôs debris as dozens of firefighters worked the scene.

card.title: NYC Mayor Says Subway Is Safe After Woman Pushed To Death In Front Of Train, Cops Disagree - The Police Tribune

_source.content:
‚ÄúNew Yorkers are safe on the subway system,‚Äù NYC Mayor Eric Adams told reporters during a press conference on Monday, according to the Daily Mail.

‚ÄúI think it‚Äôs about 1.7 percent of the crimes in New York City that occur on the subway system,‚Äù Adams said. ‚ÄúThink about that for a moment. What we must do is remove the perception of fear.‚Äù

‚ÄúCases like this aggravate the perception of fear,‚Äù he added.

But NYPD sources told The Police Tribune that crime in the city‚Äôs subway system was probably worse than statistics showed.

‚ÄúI can‚Äôt believe it‚Äôs that little,‚Äù the veteran officer said. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre out of their minds. I won‚Äôt take the subway. It‚Äôs not worth it.‚Äù

‚ÄúI supposed 1.7 percent sounds good if you want to go by statistics,‚Äù the officer said. ‚ÄúBut in reality, if you have to wonder if some nutcase is going to push you onto the tracks every time you take the train ‚Äì and it‚Äôs not just a ‚Äòwhat if‚Äô scenario because it happens on a regular basis ‚Äì then no, it‚Äôs not safe. I tell people not to take the subway on a regular basis.‚Äù

The officer said that as a former transit captain for NYPD, Adams knows the reality of what‚Äôs going on in transit and he‚Äôs disappointed in the way he sugarcoated the safety issue.

card.title: Mayor Adams admits he doesn‚Äôt feel safe riding NYC‚Äôs subways either

_source.content: https://nypost.com/2022/01/18/mayor-adams-admits-he-doesnt-feel-safe-on-trains-either/Mayor Eric Adams admitted Tuesday that even he doesn‚Äôt feel safe riding the city‚Äôs subways.‚ÄúDay one, Jan. 1, when I took the train, I saw the homelessness, the yelling, the screaming early in the morning,‚Äù said Adams, who entered office at the start of the year, during a press conference. ‚ÄúCrimes right outside the platform.‚ÄúWe know we have a job to do, and we‚Äôre going to do both: We‚Äôre going to drive down crime, and we‚Äôre going to make sure New Yorkers feel safe in our subway system,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúAnd they don‚Äôt feel that way now. I don‚Äôt feel that way when I take the train.‚ÄùAdams‚Äô stunning admission comes on the heels of his controversial comments just days ago that the tubes are safe ‚Äî and that there‚Äôs only a ‚Äúperception‚Äù that they‚Äôre not after Saturday‚Äôs random fatal shove of a straphanger at the Times Square station.As The Post reported Monday, new NYPD statistics show an ongoing spike in Big Apple transit violence, including during the first two weeks of Adams‚Äô administration.Attack in subway stationCommuters fear of riding the subway continues to increase, as more attacks occur.On Tuesday, Adams seemed to finally wise up and acknowledge straphangers‚Äô fears.‚ÄúOur system must be safe,‚Äù he said at City Hall. ‚ÄúIt must be safe from actual crime, which we are going to do. And it must be safe for those who feel as if there‚Äôs a total level of disorder in our subway system.‚ÄùSpeaking later in The Bronx, Adams said he continues to ride the trains but that ‚Äúone crime on the subway system is one crime too many.‚ÄúWe have to deal with the crime. But on Day One [in office], I took the subway system. I felt unsafe. I saw homeless everywhere, yelling on the train. There was a feeling of disorder.
_source.contentraw:
https://nypost.com/2022/01/18/mayor-adams-admits-he-doesnt-feel-safe-on-trains-either/
Mayor Eric Adams admitted Tuesday that even he doesn‚Äôt feel safe riding the city‚Äôs subways.

‚ÄúDay one, Jan. 1, when I took the train, I saw the homelessness, the yelling, the screaming early in the morning,‚Äù said Adams, who entered office at the start of the year, during a press conference. ‚ÄúCrimes right outside the platform.

‚ÄúWe know we have a job to do, and we‚Äôre going to do both: We‚Äôre going to drive down crime, and we‚Äôre going to make sure New Yorkers feel safe in our subway system,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúAnd they don‚Äôt feel that way now. I don‚Äôt feel that way when I take the train.‚Äù

Adams‚Äô stunning admission comes on the heels of his controversial comments just days ago that the tubes are safe ‚Äî and that there‚Äôs only a ‚Äúperception‚Äù that they‚Äôre not after Saturday‚Äôs random fatal shove of a straphanger at the Times Square station.

As The Post reported Monday, new NYPD statistics show an ongoing spike in Big Apple transit violence, including during the first two weeks of Adams‚Äô administration.

Attack in subway station
Commuters fear of riding the subway continues to increase, as more attacks occur.
On Tuesday, Adams seemed to finally wise up and acknowledge straphangers‚Äô fears.

‚ÄúOur system must be safe,‚Äù he said at City Hall. ‚ÄúIt must be safe from actual crime, which we are going to do. And it must be safe for those who feel as if there‚Äôs a total level of disorder in our subway system.‚Äù

Speaking later in The Bronx, Adams said he continues to ride the trains but that ‚Äúone crime on the subway system is one crime too many.

‚ÄúWe have to deal with the crime. But on Day One [in office], I took the subway system. I felt unsafe. I saw homeless everywhere, yelling on the train. There was a feeling of disorder.

card.description: Time and again, New York City‚Äôs mental-health system releases to the streets people who are a danger to at least themselves, and tragically often to innocents like Michelle Go.
card.title: Heed the pleas of the subway-shover‚Äôs sister: Stop letting the severely mentally ill roam loose and untreated

_source.content: https://nypost.com/2022/01/17/stop-letting-the-severely-mentally-ill-roam-loose-and-untreated/Even if you don‚Äôt have a loved one plagued by mental illness who refuses to get help, you have to feel for Josette Simon, the sister of the man known as Simon Martial, 61, who has admitted to the horrific Times Square murder of Michelle Go.‚ÄúI remember begging one of the hospitals, ‚ÄòLet him stay,‚Äô because once he‚Äôs out, he didn‚Äôt want to take medication, and it was the medication that kept him going,‚Äù Josette, 65, told The Post.New York City‚Äôs mental-health system (perhaps the entire nation‚Äôs) is broken. Time and again, it releases to the streets people who are a danger to at least themselves, and tragically often to innocents like Go. Even pleas from family members like Josette Simon prove futile, as the system doesn‚Äôt even use the tools available, such as Kendra‚Äôs Law, to mandate treatment.‚ÄúThere was nothing I could do,‚Äù she weeps. ‚ÄúAnd they let him out in the street.‚ÄúPeople who saw him know ‚Äî he‚Äôs crazy,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúMy brother had been sick for so long.‚Äù Diagnosed with schizophrenia decades ago, he was taken in by another sister after their mother‚Äôs death. ‚ÄúShe had to call the police on him a couple of times, but after that, he went downhill. He‚Äôs been in and out of mental hospitals at least 20 years.‚ÄùHe did state prison time after robbery and attempted robbery convictions. ‚ÄúGet him some help,‚Äù she pleads. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not saying let him out, but get him some help.‚ÄùSimon Martial's sister believes he shouldn't have been on the streets due to his mental illness.Simon Martial‚Äôs sister believes he shouldn‚Äôt have been on the streets due to his mental illness.Martial's sister said that he has been in and out of mental hospitals for 20 years before killing Go.Martial‚Äôs sister said that he has been in and out of mental hospitals for 20 years before killing Go.‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not only my brother,‚Äù she warns. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think enough people look at mental illness like a disease, like cancer, AIDS or anything else. It‚Äôs an illness.‚ÄùAn illness that requires the authorities to act ‚Äî not to leave these unfortunates roaming the streets and subways, some of them ticking time bombs.We‚Äôve called on Mayor Eric Adams to move now to change the city‚Äôs approach.
